title: Who will win the U.S. Senate election for Montana in 2020?
preds: Curious, because % in absentee ballots hasn't been reported yet.
Neck and neck race but if a landslide happens, the Democrats will win here.
Polls are breaking for Trump, likely will help down ballot candidates.

I continue to rely on EV.com¹ rather than on other aggregators, because these guys are political scientists, not just a bunch of statisticians with a news desk. ¹ https://electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Pres/averages.html (visited on Nov 1, 2020)
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Bullock is holding the slimmest of leads, this race is still very much a toss-up.

Staying below the 'crowd' consensus for now as Montana's strong early voting turnout (including those who did not vote in 2016) could be a slight 'plus' for Democrat Bullock's chances https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-29/election-2020-early-voting-turnout-in-each-state-by-the-numbers https://www.axios.com/2020-2016-vote-turnout-early-voting-e9da9e9c-df3d-46ac-ae81-2dea53e23993.html https://morningconsult.com/2020/10/29/montana-senate-polling-steve-daines-steve-bullock/
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Bullock (+3), recent polls are giving Bullock the edge. However, the polling quality still isn't that high. We'll have to stay tuned for more info.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/senate/montana/ Also,
Republicans could suffer from Chinese company’s failure to buy Montana beef
https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/10/27/montana-senate-daines-bullock-beef-china/
Still neck and neck here. Could go either way but I give a slight edge to Dems due to Covid surge.

Polls + election 'pundits' continue to slightly favor the Republican https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_Senate_election_in_Montana#General_election https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/senate/montana/

This race could go either way depending on how well Biden does nationwide.

Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
I am not so sure of the Republican win. The lead is ~ 3.4% and not widening. Polls are mixed in terms of who is leading.

Despite recent polling, 538 still has Daines at a 68% chance of pulling off the win. Given incumbency and the tilt of the state I think this is an underestimate if anything, but the race remains closer than I would have expected a few months (or even weeks) ago.

Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

This is a very close race.  However, this is looking like a blue wave election and I don't think the Senate's focus on court packing rather than economic relief is gonna be a winning strategy for Republicans.    Hell, Texas is in play.  And it is not like, Montana doesn't elect Democrats.  It does.  So for those reasons, I think the Democrats are going to pull it off in Montana.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

Only about 26 days to the election and the polls are tied.   However, due to the lack of progress on covid, the cases are rising again and the economy is slowing.   The monthly statistics (e.g., monthly unemployment GDP rates) will not come out until after the next election.  Yet, most Americans see the economy losing steam and are beginning to realize the lack of stimulus is the cause. Most American I believe will blame the Republicans for the economic slow-down  because Trump is president and they control the senate, which has failed to pass the stimulus plan. Finally, the evening news is on while I am typing, and they just said covid hospitalizations are rising in eleven states.  One of the worse is Montana.  This will hurt Republicans in Montana.

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)
Following 538 predictions.  Looks like I'm not the only one.

This has shifted from the summer, with things running even or ahead for Daines [1,2]. Since he is the incumbent, I am swinging for him. [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/montana/
[2] https://www.electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Senate/Graphs/montana.html
Trump will win Montana but they might split their ticket. Making numbers closer to the toss-up it is.
Moving forecast slightly closer to current 'crowd' consensus + 538 website forecast. https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/democrats-are-slight-favorites-to-take-back-the-senate/
Apparent edge to Daines (Republican) in polls: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/montana/
Trump is consistently ahead in the polls, which gives the R candidate an advantage.  But Bullock is popular, so it's possible for the D's to win.
Trump is consistently up 5+% and may have coattails.
Bullock has a solid chance here but his numbers are slipping.

Not-great polls for Bullock (Dem.) lately, but still two months to go. https://www.270towin.com/2020-senate-polls/montana/ https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/31/politics/election-2020-senate-races/index.html
Daines has run strong in the polls, bouncing around 50%.
Updating. Trump is slightly ahead and the coattail may extend.

Bullock is currently trailing in the RCP average and given that it is a presidential election year I find it unlikely that Montana will beat its lean. But there are a lot of wild card variables like mail-in voting and COVID.

Flipping. https://www.ktvh.com/news/election-2020/bullock-daines-mix-it-up-in-first-u-s-senate-debate
It is likely Bullock will win as he is recognized as being more independent from his party than Daines. Daines trying hard to show Bullock as radical but he has been Governor too long for people to fall for that.

https://www.businessinsider.com/steve-bullock-vs-steve-daines-montana-election-polls-fundraising-2020-8
Hard place for s Democrat to get elected though Bullock is popular. They have about the same amount of money but many big Republican PACs are helping Daines. Bullock does not have that kind of outside help. Polls? Close.
Updating based on Emerson College polling on August 3rd showing Daines with a further increasing lead.
Strong Dem candidate, former Gov., but Trump is polling very well in the state.
Bullock is great, but Montana is very red and Daines is polling well even in such a tough national environment. It's close, but I think Bullock has an uphill struggle.
The polls are close and this could go either way.

The one poll shows Bullock up and notably in the state's open the two candidates are neck and neck. Not a good sign for the GOP but I have to assume that eventually the state's lean is going to have an effect.
Steve Bullock had a lead for a while, but Montana almost always goes Republican and their incumbent is trending in the right direction.

Adjusting D -10%, R +10% https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/montana/ I still think Bullock is the favorite. I'm just too far out in front of the facts for an election that is three months away with polls inside the margin of error.

The polls continue to show Bullock ahead by around 2-4 points [1,2]. [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/montana/
[2] https://www.electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Senate/Graphs/montana.html
I just read old News From Forbes...saying that Democrats are strong in Montana
No polls available but generic congressional vote. So biasing it for that.
Bullock is an incumbent governor; strong candidate. Daines is a weak candidate.
Bullock polling well but limited data available.
Watching for more polls as we get closer to election: https://newstalkkgvo.com/new-um-big-sky-poll-shows-montana-is-still-a-red-state/
The Democrat has a seven point lead in Montana right now and the GOP is doing everything wrong right now. They need a historic turn around to avoid a catastrophic defeat.
I think nationally, swing states hit hard by covid are going to lean blue.  That's going to cause a surge in turnout in the red states that didn't suffer much under covid, like Montana.
Might need to be changed later, but as of now, I’m leaning with polls towards the democrat.
I think many Republican Montana voters will be turned off to stay home by all that has been going on the past several months. In turn it will motivate Dem voters to come out.
There just won’t be enough voters willing to go with a democrat.

Steve Bullock was ahead in a May 5th poll 46% to Daines' 39%. He's also a popular current Governor, who has a 70% approval rating for his handling of Montana's covid-19 response (while Daines only has a 48% approval rating). 72% of Montanans also said they were in favor of Bullock's stay-at-home measures. For these numbers/polls see https://www.forbes.com/sites/andrewsolender/2020/05/05/poll-shows-democrats-running-strong-in-montana/#596ec0b16590. The big asterisk is obviously that this poll was from May 5th (over a month ago), and the election is still over 4.5 months away.
Too close to call.  The numbers have been hovering around 50-50 in the prediction marmet.

Adjusting up for Daines... Bullock is the governor, and COVID cases are increasing in Montana. It looks like a potential lose-lose for him: either COVID spreads through the state, and/or Bullock implements wildly unpopular distancing measures.
Independent streak of Montana will keep it Republican.
Daines has been undistinguished. Absent a scandal, he should win. The rural votes are obviously key.

Steve Bullock is better known than his competitor, which I believe gives him advantage.Still, lots of outside money and a campaign filled with nasty ads could put it closer than I am seeing it. But in the end, with so much angst around us, I see people trending toward familiar and safe.
Blue wave will help push this over the top
Montana is running a popular democrat who is currently seven points over the Republican. I do not expect that to change.
There's 0 chance that Bullock doesn't win this! I'm original from Montana... This is the only 100% sure thing on election night!!!
Taking an average of my previous forecast and https://projects.jhkforecasts.com/senate-forecast/.
Still favoring Bullock to win, but pulling back from 59/41 to 53/47.
'Defund the police' is a political mistake for much of America that Democratic candidates may be forced to address, or defend. https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/08/politics/defund-the-police-blm/index.html
tends to be a republican state - less affected by social and economic downturn as other parts of the country
It's very hard to outperform to the extent Bullock would need to downballot from what will almost certainly be a presidential wipeout. Daines should be a strong favorite.

Polls may show a tight race and Bullock did win statewide but don't forget this is a red state in a presidential year and the general trend is the polarization of national elections and Donald Trump won this state by 20 points in 2016. Also, Bullock is up against an incumbent (albeit only a one-term incumbent) all of his statewide wins have been tight, he's behind in fundraising, and he came out for both impeachment and an assault rifle ban during the presidential run. Tester did win in 2018 and with a small state it may be hard to prescribe national trends but I need a little more evidence before I label Montana and exception to national trends.
In favor of competitiveness: Two strong candidates.  In opposition, incumbency and partisan advantage.  WIth more polling the numbers could change quite a bit.

The Montana Supreme Court voted 5-2 to halt a lower court order that had extended the absentee ballot receipt deadline for the June 2 primary election to June 8. Justice Beth Baker wrote the following in the court's majority opinion: "Election administrators have responded swiftly to ensure that ballots were timely mailed to voters across Montana. Because those ballots include express directive that they will not be counted unless received by the 8 p.m. election-day deadline, we conclude that there is good cause to maintain the election-day deadline for this primary election in order to avoid voter confusion and disruption of election administration."
Bullock is a popular moderate Democrat, but Montana is a very red state.  I think Bullock will win.  But it's not a slam dunk, so I'm hedging vis a vis the crowd (now at 62%).

The incumbent, Daines, is running against a popular democratic governor in Bullock who is getting a lot of TV time related to COVID [1]. The last poll from 538 is from early May, and show Bullock with a 10 point lead [2]. I am going to put this with a slight advantage to Bullock for now, and review again when more polling is available. [1] https://www.electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Senate/Maps/May29.html
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/montana/

It is rare for an incumbent senator to serve five years or less within Montana. It is rare for the Senate to lose more than four seats in any election year. Currently, Senator Daines has 17.9% RCP poll, beyond any reasonable margin of error. It is likely Montanans will re-elect Senator Daines with a 10+ point spread.

Daines disapproval is at FIFTY TWO percent.   Steve Bullock's approval rating is around EIGHTY percent.  Dems by 40 if the election was today.  The most popular governor in the country running against the least popular Senator..
Two-term Governor Steve Bullock is holding onto a 4 point lead at this point.
Going off of two stale polls. Until more polling I'm leaving it at an appropriate 50/50 given the data. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_Senate_election_in_Montana#Polling

Slight edge to the Democrat's chances for starters. Bullock recently has been out-raising Daines in funds but that can change. Recovery in the economy might be the most important factor going forward here and elsewhere. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_Senate_election_in_Montana#Polling https://missoulacurrent.com/government/2020/05/bullock-daines/ As others have noted, most 'pundits' currently have the race as "lean Republican" overall. https://www.270towin.com/2020-senate-election-predictions/ https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/6568/Which-party-will-win-the-US-Senate-election-in-Montana-in-2020
Predicting 60% for Daines, the incumbent, down from 85% base rate because of a slight lead for Bullock in the polls.
I absolutely presumed GOP but glimpsed at the rationales below and clearly need to do more research... sounds more interesting than I had previously thought!

The current forecasts on Fivethirtyeight.com have the Democrat, Bullock, seven points ahead of the Republican, Daines despite the fact that Trump was polling six points ahead of Biden in the May 5, 2020 poll.  It appears from the infrequent Montana polls that the best Daines has ever done in the polling is tie with Bullock.  Moreover, there are fewer polls for the senate than the presidential races in 2020. However, they seem to show that Bullock has always been popular.  He even beat Trump in an October 8, 2019, hypothetical presidential poll against Trump by four points.    Biden also appears to be narrowing the gap against Trump. The economy is bad, which will hurt all Republicans.  However, the economy should be in a slow recovery by November, which will lessen the damage to the Republicans, but by how much?   Montana might not be as Republican as I first thought when looking at this question.  The other US Senator and the Governor (Steve Bullock, now senate candidate) are both Democrats.   Bullock won his first governorship by a hair,  48.90/47.34, and his second governorship by 50.25/46.35, in a year the democrats were trounced by the Republicans.    Daines did win the 2014 election 57/40, but he has also tied himself to Trump, which I suspect will hurt him greatly.   The only approval poll I found for both was dated January 19th, 2019.  Both candidates where popular but Bullock was more popular among in his own party and among independents.  Bullock was also less unpopular in the Republican party than Daines in the Democratic party.  All in all,  I think the popular Democrat right now has the lead.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/montana/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Daines#2014_election
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_Senate_election_in_Montana#Polling
https://www.montana.edu/news/18346/bullock-daines-have-most-favorable-ratings-in-new-msu-mtn-post-election-poll

I feel the incumbent Governor going for Senate will have better success than the incumbent Senator (use FL's last senate race as an example for the success of the Governor). Bullock leads in Senate run, but race still a tie, poll says
https://www.greatfallstribune.com/story/news/2020/05/06/bullock-leads-senate-run-montana-but-race-still-tie-poll-says-steve-daines/5175578002/

A strong 3rd quarter economy will make it possible in naturally red states to see some of the GOP candidates make it to the finish line.  If the economy does not bounce back then the reverse of this prediction will hold.  However, at this time it looks like a recovery pre election day will happen.

Somewhat popular Republican incumbent. Strong polls for Bullock (D) lately, but still lean R according to Cook political and Sabato's Crystal Ball. This feels like a race that could change a lot between now and November, so we'll have to come back to this forecast a lot.
